item.title: How to Install MySQL (MariaDB) on Android With Termux
item.description:
Introduction

Generally, smartphones are not for programming but with the rapid evolution of technology the capability of smartphone is also increasing. We can do many programming stuffs on smartphone using some applications.

In this blog, we are going to use a database management system in our smartphone using termux.

We cannot run Mysql effeciently on smartphone but alternatively we can use MariaDB as our database management system. Mysql and mariadb have some similarities and differences.

MariaDB is an open-source database management system, commonly used as an alternative for the MySQL in the LAMP (Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP/Python/Perl) stack. It is intended to be a drop-in replacement for MySQL.

This tutorial will explain how to install SQL(MariaDB) or MySQL command line Android.

This is a very beginner friendly guide with explanary images.

Requirements

Download Termux App [click to expand]

Download Termux App

  • Internet connection

Step–1 Updating packages

  • Open termux app.

  • You can see a greeting screen like this :

  • Run apt update command :

  • Wait until the dollar sign appears again.

  • Now run apt upgrade command :

  • If it asks for storage permission type y and press enter :

  • If the below prompt appears, just press enter :

  • Wait for a couple of minutes.

You can clear the cluttery screen using clear command.

Step–2 Installing MariaDB (MySQL)

  • Run pkg install mariadb command :

  • Type y and press enter to give storage permission :

  • Wait until the process completes.

Step–3 Running and stoping MariaBD sessions

You have to use this step every time you need to run MariaDB.

  • Run the following command :
1mysqld_safe -u $(whoami)@localhost
  • Then your screen will look like this :

  • Now, press ctrl+z ( or open a new session)

  • Now run mariadb or mysql to start mariadb :

Do whatever you want with MariaDB, now. Create databases, tables or connect it with python for your projects.

  • To exit mariadb, type exit or quit

  • After exiting MariaDB dont forget to kill the background session completely using the below command (you can also kill sessions using pid's):

1killall -u $(whoami)

Summary

  • Update and upgrade packages using apt update & apt upgrade

  • Install mariadb package using pkg install mariadb

  • Start mariadb socket using mysqld_safe -u $(whoami)@localhost

  • Run mariadb using mariadb or mysql command

  • Exit mariadb and then kill all background processes using killall -u $(whoami)

Optionally, you can also define aliases for this commands in bash.bashrc file like this:

1alias run='mysqld_safe -u $(whoami)@localhost'

1alias stop='killall -u $(whoami)'

After that you just need to type run, mysql & stop commands instead of those long commands.

Conclusion

In this guide you installed MariaDB to act as an SQL server in android. Optionally, you also created a separate password-authenticated administrative user.
